flow.descriptionCdata:
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.05338b37-0184-4649-b20c-04e2a29381f3.description=
Retrieves process metrics using vmstat.  

Inputs\:

host -  the system to check
username - the user to log into this system as
password - the password to log in with
port - port number for connecting to the host
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success - the data was obtained
failure - the data could not be obtained

Result\:

The vmstat result.

Extra Results\:

processesSleeping - number of sleeping processes	
processesWaitingForRuntime - number of process waiting for runtime
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.0c42c7d3-e197-4975-9be3-532e3e18e163.description=
This gets the extended information from iostat using iostat -x.  Two data samples are gathered, the first one shows system averages since the last boot and the second shows the current point in time. The iostat utility may not be available in the default installation (install sysstat package). 

Inputs\:

host - hostname or ip address
port - port number for connecting to the host
username - username to connect as
password - password
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success -  the operation completed with success
failure - the operation completed with error

Result\:

The iostat return data

Extra Result\:

returnCode - the operation return code

Notice\:
This operation requires the sysstat package to be installed on the Linux machine.
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.116179af-c7e9-4b38-85d0-aea2af844f1d.callout=This flow performs a Linux system health check. The information retrieved includes memory, CPU, disk, processor and network metrics. aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.2480d3af-20ad-4b4b-a415-ee3a2302d1b2.description=
Checks a system for network errors

Inputs\:

host - the system to check
username - the user to log into this system as
password - the password to log in with
port - port number for connecting to the host
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success - the data was obtained
failure - the data could not be obtained

Result\:

The result of the check.

Extra Results\:
code - The operation return code
error - Any error data - populated by the scriptlet
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.48304af4-e095-4e4f-acd1-f1f6c1266e81.description=6c53c09c-dfcf-44e5-8f51-6986db7c59ed.b0f4dec6-2ded-4e31-929b-920c1aa35e29.description aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.5d74d4e0-7767-47d5-8927-69a36a9b4fb2.description=
This gets the number of processors on the system

Inputs\:

host\:  the system to check
username\: the user to log into this system as
password\: the password to log in with
port - port number for connecting to the host
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success - the data was obtained
failure - the data could not be obtained

Results\: 

The number of processors

Extra results\:
returnCode - The operation return code.
error - If an error occurred, the content of the error.
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.6c2419e8-7e1e-4eb9-97e7-bfe13472a8cb.description=
This operation obtains the disk usage of a Mount point or filesystem


Inputs\:

host - hostname or ip address
port - port number for connecting to the host
username - username to connect as
fiesystem - filesystem to check on
password - password
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success\: the data was obtained
failure\: the data could not be obtained

Result\:

Percent of the disk used

Extra Results\:

available\: MB available
used\: MB used
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.7f2457ca-3db2-4dd2-ab53-d6cb3b951dbf.description=
This gets the amount of uptime (in minutes).

Inputs\:

host - the system to check
username - the user to log into this system as
password - the password to log in with
port - port number for connecting to the host
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success - the data was obtained
failure - the data could not be obtained

Result\: 

Number of minutes the system has been up

Extra Results\:

code - the result code of the operation
error - if an error occurred, the content of the error.
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.83baae40-bbc6-48fb-b43b-9e02bfb42d10.description=
This gets the list of currently running process


Inputs\:

host -  the system to check
username - the user to log into this system as
password - the password to log in with
port - port number for connecting to the host
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success - the data was obtained
failure - the data could not be obtained

Result\:
returnResult - the process list using the long output format

Extra-results\:

returnCode - operation return code
error - if an error occurred the content of the error
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.9a1d2eae-09a3-4257-bf08-7dbad81937dd.description=
This gets the operating system kernel name.

Inputs\:

host\:  the system to check
username\: the user to log into this system as
password\: the password to log in with
port - port number for connecting to the host
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success\: the data was obtained
failure\: the data could not be obtained

Result\:

The OS name (uname return information)

Extra Results\:
returnCode - The return code of the operation.
error - If and error occured, the content of the error.
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.a2754df6-f203-44bd-b5ef-12c74f68d983.description=
Runs a Ping command either locally or remotely depending on the specified protocol. Credentials and other inputs (remoteOS, hostname, username, password, keyFile etc) are required if the command must be run from a remote host. The Telnet protocol also requires inputs for usernamePrompt and passwordPrompt. 

Inputs\:
    hostname - Hostname or IP address of the host computer where the Ping command will be executed.
    username - A username to authenticate to the host computer. 
    password - The password for the user account.
    targetHost - Hostname or IP address of the target host computer.
    protocol  - The protocol used to run the command.
Valid values\: local, ssh, Telnet
    packetSize - The size of the ping packet.
    packetCount - The number of ping packets to send.
    remoteOS - The operating system of the host computer (WINDOWS, LINUX, SOLARIS only are supported), if Ping is running on a remote host.
    usernamePrompt - The username prompt seen while using Telnet protocol. This input is required when Telnet protocol is used. For example, login\:.
    passwordPrompt - The password prompt seen while using Telnet protocol. This input is required when Telnet protocol is used. For example, password\:.
    keyFile - The path to the private key file for remote host. The path should be absolute.
    timeout - The timeout in miliseconds for the Ping operation. Default is 90000.

Responses\:
    success - The command executed successfully.
    failure - The command could not be executed or had a problem during execution.

Returns\:
    packetsSent - The number of packets sent.
    packetsReceived - The number of packets received.
    percentagePacketsLost - The percentage of packets lost.
    transmissionTimeMin - Minimum time taken for transmitting the packet.
    transmissionTimeMax - Maximum time taken for transmitting the packet.
    transmissionTimeAvg - Average time taken for transmitting the packet.
    returnResult - Raw output of the command.
    returnCode - Return code of the executed command.
    error - The STDERR of the command.
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.abff38cc-76d2-40dc-805c-44370df90159.description=
Runs a command and allows the user to specify that it runs locally (in this case no port should be specified), via ssh, Global Shell, ROSH, Telnet, or RSH.

Inputs\:
    host - The hostname or ip address.
    port - The port number for connecting to the host.
    username - The username to connect as.
    password - The password of the user. If using a private key file, this will be used as the passphrase for the file.
    protocol - The protocol used to run the command.
Valid values\: ssh, ROSH, Telnet, GlobalShell, RSH, local, WMI, NASConnectTelnet, HPOM, REXEC
    timeout - The time in seconds to wait for the command to complete. After the timeout has expired the remote process and all child processes will be terminated. Increase its value if you are getting incomplete output results or timeout. 
Default value\: 90
    command - The command to execute.
    arguments - The arguments to pass to the command.
    environment - Specifies environment variables/values that need to be defined when running command.
    startDir - The path to the starting directory.
    pty - Whether to use pty (used by ssh, GlobalShell).
Valid values\: True, False
Default value\: False
    privateKeyFile - The path to the private key file, relative to ICONCLUDE_HOME on RAS host (used by ssh, GlobalShell).
    sasHost - The host we want to run the ROSH command on.
    sasHostUsername - The username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost.
    usernamePrompt - The prompt that when seen should send the username. This is only used by the Telnet protocol. When used by the NASConnectTelnet protocol, the default value is 'NAS Login\:'.
    passwordPrompt - The prompt that when given should send the password. This is only used by the Telnet protocol. When used by the NASConnectTelnet protocol, the default value is 'Password\:'.
    outputPath - The network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified, it points to '\\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible', you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default, the path will have to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    nasDevice - The NAS device to run the command on when using the NASConnect protocol.
    nasDeviceConsoleMode - The NAS device console mode used to run the command scripts that run the command on the given NAS device. If this input is empty, command scripts are not used, and the connection to the NAS device and the command are issued directly in the console. This is not recommended, since its error handling capabilities are limited and it might result in success even when the command fails to execute. The values for this input can be found in the NAS web interface, as a drop-down list when a new command script is created (ex. Cisco IOS enable).
    hpomNode - The node on which the command is to be executed.
    hpomProtocol - The protocol to communicate with HPOM.
Valid values\: http, https
    characterSet - The characterSet name for stream encoding and decoding between the RAS and target machine. 
Examples\: SJIS, EUC-JP, UTF-8
Default value\: UTF-8 (used by ssh, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, REXEC)

Responses\:
    success - The command was executed successfully.
    failure - The command could not be executed.

Extra Results\:
    stdErr - The STDERR of the command.
    stdOut - The STDOUT of the command.

Note\:
Telnet protocol - Since telnet is not a remote execution protocol but a shell protocol, the response will always be successful if the command was executed in the remote shell.  The return code of the specified command cannot be determined in this protocol.  If you must use the telnet protocol with this operation besure to check the command results. Consider using ssh or rexec protocol instead.
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.ac91852e-145f-47cd-9b13-ee54228d1251.description=
This retrieves CPU utilization metrics using vmstat

Inputs\:

host\:  the system to check
username\: the user to log into this system as
password\: the password to log in with
port - port number for connecting to the host
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success\: the data was obtained
failure\: the data could not be obtained

Result\:

The raw result of the vmstat command

Extra Results\:

busyPercent - what percent of the CPU is busy
userPercent - the percent of the CPU used by user processes
idlePercent - what percent of the CPU is idle
ioWait - CPU IO Wait percent
systemPercent - the percent of the CPU used by system processes
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.d0231e7c-c899-443c-9e40-ae9891046962.description=
Get the list of file systems on the machine

Inputs\:

host - hostname or ip address
port - port number for connecting to the host
username - username to connect as
password - password
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success\: the data was obtained
failure\: the data could not be obtained

Result\:

A table of file system names and percent full sorted with the most full system first.  Note that the percent full is the first column in the table and the name is the second column.  The first row of the table are column headers.  For example\:

Use%     Mounted
66%       /
16%       /boot
0%         /dev/shm
Extra Results\: returnCode - the operation return code error - if an error occured, the content of the error aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.d37f7dc9-8f11-44e3-b10b-08397ece3ef3.description=
This gets the load averages from the uptime command

Inputs\:

host\:  the system to check
username\: the user to log into this system as
password\: the password to log in with
port - port number for connecting to the host
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success - the data was obtained
failure - the data could not be obtained

Result\:

The uptime return code

Extra Results\:
returnResult - the output string
oneMinute - the one minute load average
fiveMinute - the five minute load average
fifteenMinute - the fifteen minute load average
error - if an error occurred the content of the error
aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.description=
 This flow performs a Linux health check by pinging the system and then running several commands and collecting information regarding the operating system, CPUs, disks, networks, memory and processes.

Inputs\:
    host - The hostname or IP address of the Linux system to perform the health check on.
    username - The user to connect to the host. Not required for localhost.
    password - The password to connect to the host. Not required for localhost.
    diskName - The disk name (Device) to check.
Default value\: /dev/sda

Responses\:
    success - Host health check completed.
    failure - An error occurred when pinging the server, the health check could not be performed.

Results\:
    averageReadsPerSec - The average number of read requests that were issued to the device per second.
    averageWritesPerSec - The average number of write requests that were issued to the device per second.
    cpuMetrics - The result of the vmstat command.
    diskMetrics - The disk metrics for the system.
    diskUsage - Percentage of the disk used.
    extendedIO - The result of the iostat command.
    freeMemory - The number of megabytes of unused memory.
    fsList - A table of file system names and percentage usage sorted descending by used space.
    loadAverage - The one minute load average.
    memoryMetrics - Detailed information regarding the memory.
    networkInterfaces - The result of the check for network errors on the system.
    networkMetrics - The result of the netstat command.
    osName - The operating system name (uname return information).
    osType - The operating system type ( linux ).
    osVersion - The version of the operating system.
    processList - The process list using the long output format.
    processesSleeping - The number of sleeping processes.
    processesWaitingForRuntime - The number of processes waiting for runtime.
    processorCount - The number of processors.
    totalMemory - The number of megabytes of total memory.
    uptime - The number of minutes the system has been up.
    used - The number of Megabytes of the disk used.
    usedMemory - The number of megabytes of used memory.

Note\: 
If the operating system is Ubuntu, an additional package (sysstat) needs to be installed on the target in order to retrieve two of the metrics  (Disk and Extended IO), using the iostat command. 
If sysstat is not installed, the execution of those two steps will fail and the information will not be present in the report.

In order to install sysstat, use the following commands\:

1) download the package from the Ubuntu repository \: sudo apt-get update
2) install the package sysstat \: sudo apt-get install sysstat

aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.e70c40d2-2e81-4ee1-8f2d-4caa98de3e45.description=
This retrieves memory metrics using top.  

Inputs\:

host\:  the system to check
username\: the user to log into this system as
password\: the password to log in with
port - port number for connecting to the host
protocol - the protocol used to run the command (can be one of ssh, ROSH, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, local or WMI)
timeout - (optional, default 90 seconds) time in milliseconds to wait for the command to complete
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty
privateKeyFile - path to private key file
sasHost - the host we want to run the ROSH command on
sasHostUsername - the username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost
usernamePrompt - the prompt that when seen should send the username
passwordPrompt - the prompt that when given should send the password

Responses\:

success\: the data was obtained
failure\: the data could not be obtained

Result\:

the return code from the vmstat command

Extra Results\:

activeMemory - the number of megabytes of active memory.
bufferMemory - the number of megabytes of buffer memory.
freeMemory - the number of megabytes of unused memory.
freeSwap - the number of megabytes of unused swap.
inactiveMemory - the number of megabytes of inactive memory.
sharedMemory - the number of megabytes of shared memory.
swapCache - the number of megabytes of swap cache.
totalMemory	- the number of megabytes of total memory.
totalSwap - the number of megabytes of total swap space.
usedMemory - the number of megabytes of used memory.
usedSwap - the number of megabytes of used swap.
error - if an error occurred, the content of the error
returnCode - the operation return code


aae35f7f-b2a2-4fa0-b210-5a1fcc58875f.fdb5237c-c578-4dc0-868c-2a4955569c94.description=
Runs a command and allows the user to specify that it runs locally (in this case no port should be specified), via ssh, Global Shell, ROSH, Telnet, or RSH.

Inputs\:
    host - The hostname or ip address.
    port - The port number for connecting to the host.
    username - The username to connect as.
    password - The password of the user. If using a private key file, this will be used as the passphrase for the file.
    protocol - The protocol used to run the command.
Valid values\: ssh, ROSH, Telnet, GlobalShell, RSH, local, WMI, NASConnectTelnet, HPOM, REXEC
    timeout - The time in seconds to wait for the command to complete. After the timeout has expired the remote process and all child processes will be terminated. Increase its value if you are getting incomplete output results or timeout. 
Default value\: 90
    command - The command to execute.
    arguments - The arguments to pass to the command.
    environment - Specifies environment variables/values that need to be defined when running command.
    startDir - The path to the starting directory.
    pty - Whether to use pty (used by ssh, GlobalShell).
Valid values\: True, False
Default value\: False
    privateKeyFile - The path to the private key file, relative to ICONCLUDE_HOME on RAS host (used by ssh, GlobalShell).
    sasHost - The host we want to run the ROSH command on.
    sasHostUsername - The username used to run the ROSH command on sasHost.
    usernamePrompt - The prompt that when seen should send the username. This is only used by the Telnet protocol. When used by the NASConnectTelnet protocol, the default value is 'NAS Login\:'.
    passwordPrompt - The prompt that when given should send the password. This is only used by the Telnet protocol. When used by the NASConnectTelnet protocol, the default value is 'Password\:'.
    outputPath - The network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified, it points to '\\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible', you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default, the path will have to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    nasDevice - The NAS device to run the command on when using the NASConnect protocol.
    nasDeviceConsoleMode - The NAS device console mode used to run the command scripts that run the command on the given NAS device. If this input is empty, command scripts are not used, and the connection to the NAS device and the command are issued directly in the console. This is not recommended, since its error handling capabilities are limited and it might result in success even when the command fails to execute. The values for this input can be found in the NAS web interface, as a drop-down list when a new command script is created (ex. Cisco IOS enable).
    hpomNode - The node on which the command is to be executed.
    hpomProtocol - The protocol to communicate with HPOM.
Valid values\: http, https
    characterSet - The characterSet name for stream encoding and decoding between the RAS and target machine. 
Examples\: SJIS, EUC-JP, UTF-8
Default value\: UTF-8 (used by ssh, GlobalShell, Telnet, RSH, REXEC)

Responses\:
    success - The command was executed successfully.
    failure - The command could not be executed.

Extra Results\:
    stdErr - The STDERR of the command.
    stdOut - The STDOUT of the command.

Note\:
Telnet protocol - Since telnet is not a remote execution protocol but a shell protocol, the response will always be successful if the command was executed in the remote shell.  The return code of the specified command cannot be determined in this protocol.  If you must use the telnet protocol with this operation besure to check the command results. Consider using ssh or rexec protocol instead.
flow.name: Linux Health Check
